Six party talks are unusual, so the probability of them occurring in any 40-day period is low. Additionally, the conditions aren't right for talks to occur: all the parties need to believe that the other parties are motivated to adhere to the terms of any deal that is reached, but a deal brokered by the Obama administration would lack that credibility as soon as Donald Trump is inaugurated. This means that the parties should be highly unmotivated to pursue talks.

SEOUL (Reuters) - North Korean leader Kim Jong Un supervised a ground test of a new rocket engine to launch satellites, the North's state media reported on Tuesday, the latest in a rapid succession of missile-related tests this year by the isolated state.
Kim asked scientists and engineers to make "preparations for launching the satellite as soon as possible on the basis of the successful test," the official KCNA news agency said, indicating the North may soon launch another long-range rocket.
The test was conducted amid global condemnation of the North's fifth nuclear test earlier this month and a call by the United States, Japan and South Korea this week for greater pressure on Pyongyang over its disregard for United Nations resolutions banning missile and nuclear programs (para 1-3).

SEOUL North Korea has made considerable progress this year on weapons technology, including testing a submarine-launched missile for the first time, but it's still not clear if the isolated nation has developed a nuclear warhead.
It also does not yet have a fleet of submarines that can launch the newly developed missile. 
Nevertheless, concerns about the threat posed by North Korea have spiraled since it conducted its fourth nuclear explosion in January and followed it up with a series of missile tests despite severe United Nations sanctions. 
Also, three major factories known to produce machine parts for North Korea's sanctioned nuclear and missile programs have been modernized or expanded, according to analysis of recent satellite imagery seen by Reuters, a further sign of its commitment of scarce resources to weapons (para. 1-3).

There is a 9% chance that the six party talks on North Korea’s nuclear weapons program resume before January 1, 2017. Despite the sanctions placed on North Korea by the UN, there is a low likelihood that North Korea will rejoin six party talks because Kim Jong Un has declared that he will never join them again after 2009.

North Korea has publicly announced that they will not rejoin talks, and have even responded to UN sanctions by testing their weapons. The only force pressing for these talks is the other countries, and North Korea is more likely to pursue their own goals than respond to any of these countries.

Background:
North and South Korea have been at war for over 60 years, but have been in a cease fire for the majority of that time. Tensions between the two countries have increased as North Korea has begun developing and testing missiles in an effort to create nuclear weapons. To find a diplomatic solution, there have been several attempts at peace talks between the 6 most involved countries, the United States, North Korea, South Korea, China, Russia and Japan. North Korea has joined and withdrawn from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty on multiple occasions. Talks between the countries restarted most recently in 2003 resulting in a pledge by North Korea to denuclearize in 2005. However, by 2009 these agreements had broken down after a North Korean rocket launch. Since then, North Korea has said it will never rejoin negotiations while the other countries still claim to be open to negotiating.

In the past they have reached agreements but North Korea broke the agreement and then that they would never rejoin talks with the other countries. The five other countries said they would re-talk if North Korea was willing. A regime change could happen or another wildcard which could change the outcome entirely. I think that this is a 8% chance of happening because there is a low chance of Kim Jong Un being helpful to other countries and he has shown that he is against cooperating with the six countries through peace talks.

The five parties excluding North Korea are all willing to discuss this nuclear program, however North Korea isn’t willing to come together and discuss these things, as they showed in 2009 when they claimed that these six-party talks wouldn’t ever happen because they don’t believe that they needed to happen. However, there is still a chance that a regime change may happen before then (most likely with the passing of Kim Jong Un), which might open them up to discussions regarding their nuclear program.

A fully and permanently denuclearized Korean peninsula is an admirable goal, but this desire for CVID should be tempered with the understanding that technological advancement may not be reversible; true irreversibility may well be unattainable. In the near term, the best that the international community may be able to accomplish is to prevent North Korea from gaining additional technical knowledge or acquiring materials for its weapons program by enforcing Security Council sanctions. The long-term goal should be to welcome North Korea back to the nonproliferation regime and address its security concerns, thereby eliminating its impulse to possess nuclear weapons in the first place.

Before six party talks can resume, there should be some semblance of diplomatic activity. I see none at this time. From 2003-2009, six-party talks went back and forth with no final agreement.  In 2014, Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov indicated that North Korea wanted to resume talks. However, 2015 brought no movement towards the resumption of talks. 
Outside view: When talks were happening, the average was about 1 round per year for 6 years (2003-2009). Total of 6 rounds. But there have been zero rounds in the last 6 years. The numbers indicate another round is due. Based on this reasoning, I'd estimate 30% for resumption by year end. 
Inside view: However, the difference in leadership since the last talks and the recent nuclear test make resumption of talks seem less imminent. In addition, the complicated relationships between the U.S, China and Russia make things harder still.  In terms of domestic politics, it's not clear how much diplomacy the Obama administration is willing to devote to this issue in the last year of power. Although if there is to be any significant impact of the 'pivot toward Asia' one might be tempted to think that Obama's team would be pursuing some progress on North Korea. Still, these things would have to happen early in the year for talks to get underway in time for some kind of new framework. I'm estimating these thoughts are worth about a minus 15 (-15). That leaves me at 15% for now.

China has all countries in check with regards to North Korea, and it's not high-priority.  Unless North Korea becomes attention-seeking and tests some more nuclear weapons, it's unlikely talks will resume, and if they do they will be preparatory and posturing rather than substantive.

N. Korea is going to want something in exchange for coming back to the table.   As nuclear disarmament is an important issue for President Obama, he would probably be happy to induce Kim to come back to the table (and after seeing the deals the Cubans and Iranians got,  Kim would be wise to think big).   However, I don't see China, Japan nor S. Korea being particularly interested at this time in bribing Kim to restart talks.

One ought never to underestimate the importance of theatre--or more precisely, of choreography--in international relations.  A performance of "Swan Lake" does not change the external world much, but brings gratification to the audience and remuneration to the company.  
Like "Swan Lake," chats with the DPRK can commence with minimal set construction, not much special costuming, little rehearsal since everyone knows the show already, and no expectation of "results." Odette dies and everybody gets back on the bus and goes home, neither surprised nor disappointed.

While no real activity has occurred since 2009, the nuclear issue has been raised recently by South Korea with some of the other 5 parties (most recent news I could find included talks with US negotiators and calls by SK for Russia to begin pushing this issue).  There also appear to have been material developments in North Korean ballistic missiles, with a new ICBM displayed in recent military parades (Oct) and some improvements made to launch sites in recent months.  Although talks have been suspended for the last 6+ years (and no real news has surfaced recently regarding resumption), it is sometimes the case that changes (particularly improvements) in perceived capability of North Korea have led to resumption of talks in the past.
